Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[tests] Enable diagnostic logging for `make V=1`" (#1647) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
The [xamarin-android Jenkins job][0] isn't green, but it's not because
of any failing unit tests; 81ef825a fixed the last known unit test
failure.

[0]: https://jenkins.mono-project.com/view/Xamarin.Android/job/xamarin-android/

This leaves us wondering: what's broken *now*?

Fortunately we have logs, e.g. [build #987][1]:

[1]: https://jenkins.mono-project.com/view/Xamarin.Android/job/xamarin-android/987/

	Resources/drawable/android_button.xml(4): error APT0000: No resource found that matches the given name (at 'drawable' with value '@drawable/AndroidPressed'). […/xamarin-android/src/Mono.Android/Test/Mono.Android-Tests.csproj]
	Resources/drawable/android_button.xml(4): error APT0000: No resource found that matches the given name (at 'drawable' with value '@drawable/AndroidPressed'). […/xamarin-android/src/Mono.Android/Test/Mono.Android-Tests.csproj]
	…/xamarin-android/build-tools/scripts/RunTests.targets(87,5): error MSB3073: The command "…/xamarin-android/build-tools/scripts/../../bin/Release/bin/xabuild …/xamarin-android/build-tools/scripts/../../src/Mono.Android/Test/Mono.Android-Tests.csproj /t:SignAndroidPackage /p:Configuration=Release /p:XAIntegratedTests=False /p:AotAssemblies=True" exited with code 1.

Now we know why it's failing, we review the log file, and...

There's no diagnostic output for that failing build.

(Insert screaming & crying here.)

Fortunately we've been able to since repro the issue (fix pending),
but that's not quite the point/problem.

The problem is that figuring out what went wrong with the above
command would have been *much* easier if we had diagnostic output.

Update the e.g. `RunApkTests` MSBuild target so that if the `$V`
environment variable is not an empty string, we add `/v:diag` to
`xabuild` invocations. This permits straightforward `make` use:

	$ make run-all-tests CONFIGURATION=Release V=1
	# Unit test builds *also* produce diagnostic build output!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue ""make install" fails because of bogus Makefile script" (#1648) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
This is what happens when you run `make prefix=/devel install` while you already have `/devel/lib/xamarin.android` .

	$ make prefix=/devel install
	tr: warning: an unescaped backslash at end of string is not portable
	tr: warning: an unescaped backslash at end of string is not portable
	mkdir -p "/devel/bin"
	mkdir -p "/devel/lib/mono/xbuild-frameworks"
	mkdir -p "/devel/lib/xamarin.android"
	mkdir -p "/devel/lib/mono/xbuild/Xamarin/"
	# -rm -rf "/devel/lib/xamarin.android/" # FIXME: delete it
	cp -a "bin/Debug/lib/xamarin.android/" "/devel/lib/xamarin.android/"
	rm -rf "/devel/lib/mono/xbuild/Xamarin/Android"
	rm -rf "/devel/lib/mono/xbuild-frameworks/MonoAndroid"
	ln -s "/devel/lib/xamarin.android/xbuild/Xamarin/Android/" "/devel/lib/mono/xbuild/Xamarin/Android"
	ln -s "/devel/lib/xamarin.android/xbuild/Novell/" "/devel/lib/mono/xbuild/Novell"
	ln: failed to create symbolic link '/devel/lib/mono/xbuild/Novell/Novell': File exists
	Makefile:39: recipe for target 'install' failed
	make: *** [install] Error 1

This is the problematic use of `cp`: https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/blob/master/Makefile#L47

Actually I made a change before running it - `# -rm -rf "/devel/lib/xamarin.android/"`. By enabling this line it will work.

Maybe this is unsophisticated use of `cp` based on Mac experience.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Exception in GenerateJavaStubs" (#1431) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new Android project in Visual Studio (Single View App)
2. Run the `SetupDependenciesForDesigner` target with property `DesignTimeBuild` set to true and `AndroidUseManagedDesignTimeResourceGenerator` set to false.

### Expected Behavior

The target completes successfully-ish

### Actual Behavior

InvalidOperationException in `GenerateJavaStubs`:

```
[2018-03-15 18:19:43.6] WARN: : MSBuild error: C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\Dogfood\Enterprise\MSBuild\Xamarin\Android\Xamarin.Android.Common.Debugging.targets(571,2) MSB4018 The "GenerateJavaStubs" task failed unexpectedly.
System.InvalidOperationException: Sequence contains no elements
   at System.Linq.Enumerable.Max(IEnumerable`1 source)
   at Java.Interop.Tools.JavaCallableWrappers.TypeNameMapGenerator.WriteBinaryMapping(Stream o, Dictionary`2 mapping)
   at Java.Interop.Tools.JavaCallableWrappers.TypeNameMapGenerator.WriteJavaToManaged(Stream output)
   at Xamarin.Android.Tasks.GenerateJavaStubs.UpdateWhenChanged(String path, Action`1 generator)
   at Xamarin.Android.Tasks.GenerateJavaStubs.WriteTypeMappings(List`1 types)
   at Xamarin.Android.Tasks.GenerateJavaStubs.Run(DirectoryAssemblyResolver res)
   at Xamarin.Android.Tasks.GenerateJavaStubs.Execute()
   at Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.TaskExecutionHost.Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.ITaskExecutionHost.Execute()
   at Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.TaskBuilder.<ExecuteInstantiatedTask>d__26.MoveNext()
```

### Version Information

15.7

### Log File

Events.RelatedBody: Building an apk breaks without libzip.so.4 present

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] Check `javac -version`" (#1644) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
@directhex notes:

> Jdk and jre aren't the same thing.
> If jre (java) is 8 but Jdk (javac) is 9, javac throws exit 2
> Yes I know it's an edge case
> But we should check both java and javac version for XA0030

Update `<ResolveSdks/>` to validate versions from *both*
`java -version` *and* `javac -version`, to ensure that we don't
inadvertently use JDK 9 tooling (see also 9c9e5e53).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "XAML designer code-behinds require solution reload to make IDE aware of changes" (#2612) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description

The title says it all, really. I change the XAML in such a way that requires the designer code file be rewritten (say, add or change an `x:Name`), then I rebuild the solution. The code editor for the code-behind does _not_ update with the new value of the file until the solution is closed and reopened. Needless to say, this gets really annoying really fast.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download the attached test case
2. Open it in VS 2017 for Windows
3. Open MainPage.xaml, and change `x:Name="RedBox"` to read `x:Name="RedBox2"`.
4. Open the MainPage.cs file. Note how VS thinks the RedBox variable is still present, even though the compiler knows it isn't (build and you will get an error).

### Expected Behavior

Any change in the designer file should be picked up by VS automatically.

### Actual Behavior

I have to close and reload the solution to force VS to reread the generated designer files.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: VS for Windows 15.6.7
- Last known good version: Don't know
- IDE: Visual Studio for Windows
- Platform Target Frameworks: Doesn't apply, this is a designer problem
- Android Support Library Version: N/A
- Nuget Packages: Xamarin.Forms v3.0.0-296286-pre2, no others
- Affected Devices: All of them, this is a designer problem.

### Reproduction Link

[XamFormsTest.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/1977271/XamFormsTest.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[UWP] Setting Span BackgroundColor has no effect on UWP" (#2611) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
Setting the Span BackgroundColor in a FormattedText of a label has no effect on UWP. iOS and Android do work fine.

### Steps to Reproduce
Create a Label with a FormattedText and use Spans. Set the background color of the span. Reproduction solution attached.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Net Standard Project csproj build instructions differs from PCL csproj which affects Android" (#2610) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
I could not see the same results on the Android from a project ported from an existing PCL sample to a NET Std project created from scratch but using the PCL code modules.
### Steps to Reproduce
I followed the instructions from the website : 
https://montemagno.com/how-to-convert-a-pcl-library-to-net-standard-and-keep-git-history/
to convert the WorkingWithImages sample to a Net Standard version of the sample. The Android target worked just as the PCL version.
However when I attempted to create a new NET Std project and add the existing sample code to this project I got different results on the Android. After comparing the differences in the files of these 2 projects, I discovered some lines in the ported PCL csproj file that were not in the NET Standard csproj file. The following lines were in the ported PCL csproj (now a Net Standard csproj file) file but not in the Net Standard csproj file created as a new project:
`<ItemGroup> <EmbeddedResource Update="EmbeddedImagesXaml.xaml"> <Generator>MSBuild:Compile</Generator> </EmbeddedResource> </ItemGroup>`
When I added these lines to the new project Net Standard csproj file, the code produced the same results on the Android as the ported PCL sample project.
1. Look at the 2 zipped projects I uploaded for repoing the bug #2597. The first one I created as a new Net Standard project. The 2nd I created by stripping my ported PCL project.

### Description of Change ###

fixes #2607

Added ConfigureAwait(false) to the process waiting for the dialog to close so as to not cause a deadlock with the await in the while loop above it

```C#
options.SetResult(await s_currentAlert.ConfigureAwait(false));
```

Also slightly modified the Bugzilla test that started this all to include the case which was causing the deadlocks on UWP

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "OnPlatform/OnIdiom markup extensions" (#2608) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description

Sometimes changing a single property value per platform is quite convenient, yet the "full" syntax of `OnPlatform` is overkill for scalar values in attributes. 

For example:

```xml
<Label Text="Hello World">
    <Label.FontSize>
        <OnPlatform x:TypeArguments="x:Double">
            <On Platform="iOS" Value="20" />
            <On Platform="Android" Value="24" />
        </OnPlatform>
    </Label.FontSize>
</Label>
```

vs a markup extension version that could provide:

```xml
<Label Text="Hello World" FontSize="{OnPlatform Android=24, iOS=20}" />
```

Same thing applies for `OnIdiom`, so I think both would make XAML much more concise.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[runtime] add support for mono runtime interpreter" (#3058) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
The mono runtime ships an interpreter since a few releases. This PR adds an option so that the interpreter can be used instead of the AOT compiler machinery, by passing `--interpreter` to `mtouch`.

The runtime footprint is a bit larger than with the AOT approach, but we are paying the cost of the runtime overhead only when the `--interpreter` option is used, by linking additional libraries to the existing AOT runtime.

The `--interpreter` option still needs the AOT compiler in order to compile a few trampolines/wrappers ahead of time that are used by the interpreter. Those end up in `mscorlib.dll.o`. This is much smaller than it would be in the AOT case. Other DLLs won't be AOT compiled.

With the interpreter we pass the mini regression test suite which serves as initial smoke test. More tests will be enabled over time.

Fixes https://github.com/mono/mono/issues/6916
